docs.snippet: Colombia's government announced today that it would investigate reports that Venezuelan military officers met with Colombian rebels inside Colombian territory, in an episode that has strained relations between the two neighbors.    The announcemen...
docs.lead_paragraph: Colombia's government announced today that it would investigate reports that Venezuelan military officers met with Colombian rebels inside Colombian territory, in an episode that has strained relations between the two neighbors. The announcement by Colombia's foreign minister, Guillermo Fernández de Soto, came a day after four Venezuelan journalists released a grainy videotape in Carácas showing Colombian guerrillas warmly receiving a delegation of Venezuelan military officers on July 6, 2000.
docs.abstract: Colombia's government says it will investigate reports that Venezuelan military officers met with Colombian rebels inside Colombian territory, in episode that has strained relations between two neighbors; Venezuelan journalists release grainy videotape showing Colombian guerrillas warmly receiving delegation of Venezuelan military officers on July 6, 2000; this raises questions about possible ties between Pres Hugo Chavez's left-leaning government and Colombia's largest rebel group, Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia; Chavez has often broken diplomatic protocol to rebuke Colombia, accusing Pres Andres Pastrana of being too close to United States; Chavez denies that his government has had direct ties to Colombian rebels, but he will not rule out future encounters (M)

headline.main: Colombia Fears Ties Between Its Rebels and Venezuela Military

docs.snippet: The European Union has notified Khartoum of its decision to resume development aid after more than a decade. A European Commission representative in Sudan, Xavier Marchal, said he had handed President Omar al-Bashir ''formal notification that the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The European Union has notified Khartoum of its decision to resume development aid after more than a decade. A European Commission representative in Sudan, Xavier Marchal, said he had handed President Omar al-Bashir ''formal notification that the preparation for the programming of the Cotonou Agreement can start.'' Sudan was a signatory to that agreement, which allows African, Caribbean and Pacific nations to receive European Union aid, but the commission suspended Sudan's in 1990 because of rights issues in a long-running civil war. The move will allow Sudan to recoup arrears totaling $130 million.
docs.abstract: European Union will resume development aid to Sudan, suspended in 1990 because of rights issues in long-running civil war; move will let Sudan recoup arrears of $130 million (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Aid From Europe To Resume

docs.snippet: At a rural Philippine Army base here, beyond a grove of tamarind trees shading a turkey pen and a cow pasture, construction teams are working around the clock, preparing for a new step by the United States in the global war on terrorism.    Racing...
docs.lead_paragraph: At a rural Philippine Army base here, beyond a grove of tamarind trees shading a turkey pen and a cow pasture, construction teams are working around the clock, preparing for a new step by the United States in the global war on terrorism. Racing a deadline of Jan. 25, workers are bolting together prefabricated steel dormitories, classrooms and a mess hall to house 160 of the American troops who are to come here. They are to train and advise Filipino soldiers in their war against Abu Sayyaf guerrillas, who hold an American couple hostage on the nearby island of Basilan.
docs.abstract: Most residents of Zamboanga, Philipines, where American military troops will be housed, give at last qualified support to United States mission to train and advise Filipino soldiers in their war against Abu Sayyaf guerrillas, who hold American couple hostage in nearby island of Basilan; photo (M)

headline.main: U.S. Mission Lifts Filipino Hopes for Peace

docs.snippet: The White House said today that President Bush had not asked for clemency for Lori Berenson, the American serving a 20-year jail sentence in Peru after being convicted of helping rebels plan a 1995 attempt to capture the country's Congress.    The...
docs.lead_paragraph: The White House said today that President Bush had not asked for clemency for Lori Berenson, the American serving a 20-year jail sentence in Peru after being convicted of helping rebels plan a 1995 attempt to capture the country's Congress. The Associated Press reported on Monday that Peru's vice president, Raúl Diez Canseco, had told a cable news channel in Peru that Mr. Bush suggested ''something about clemency'' for Ms. Berenson during talks that Mr. Bush had with President Alejandro Toledo of Peru in Lima.
docs.abstract: White House denies report Pres Bush sought clemency for Lori Berenson, American jailed in Peru for alleged role in 1995 rebel attempt to capture nation's Congress, during talks with Pres Alejandro Toledo (S)

docs.snippet: The Bush administration hopes to use concern over terrorism to build support in Congress for direct aid to the Colombian government to fight leftist rebels, officials say.    American policy makers have not decided how deeply they want to plunge i...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration hopes to use concern over terrorism to build support in Congress for direct aid to the Colombian government to fight leftist rebels, officials say. American policy makers have not decided how deeply they want to plunge into Colombia's fight against the country's main rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known by its Spanish acronym FARC. So far the American commitment has been to share intelligence and to rush spare parts to Colombia.
docs.abstract: Bush administration hopes to use concern over terrorism to build support in Congress for direct aid to Colombian government to fight leftist rebels; Pres Bush says US will continue to comply with laws restricting American military involvement in Colombia to war on drugs, but administration officials are beginning to portray Colombian government's struggle as part of broader, worldwide fight against terrorists, and they say it deserves military support program; Sen Bob Graham says Colombia's instability must be viewed as regional security threat; says administration is sending conflicting signals; Secretary of State Colin Powell and national secuity adviser Condoleezza Rice are known to be urging cautious approach to Pres Andres Pastrana's appeal for military help (M)

headline.main: U.S. to Explore Aid to Colombia, Citing Threat of Terrorism

docs.snippet: A Gypsy group sued I.B.M. because it leased punch-card tabulating machinery to the Nazis, enabling them to identify and kill at least 600,000 Gypsies. Gypsy International Recognition and Compensation Action sued in Geneva, the location of the comp...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Gypsy group sued I.B.M. because it leased punch-card tabulating machinery to the Nazis, enabling them to identify and kill at least 600,000 Gypsies. Gypsy International Recognition and Compensation Action sued in Geneva, the location of the company's European headquarters, on behalf of five Gypsies whose parents died in concentration camps. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
docs.abstract: Gypsy International Recognition and Compensation Action sues IBM for its leasing of punch-card tabulating machines to Nazis, which helped regime identify and kill at least 600,000 Nazis (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Gypsies Sue I.B.M.

docs.snippet: Gen. Pervez Musharraf's new crackdown on violent Islamic groups in Pakistan, which has already led to dozens of arrests, is a momentous development that should help defuse the confrontation with India. It was reassuring, as well, for India to reac...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gen. Pervez Musharraf's new crackdown on violent Islamic groups in Pakistan, which has already led to dozens of arrests, is a momentous development that should help defuse the confrontation with India. It was reassuring, as well, for India to react by welcoming the decision by General Musharraf, the Pakistani leader, which he announced over the weekend. Understandably, India now insists that General Musharraf's words be matched by deeds in the disputed Muslim-dominated state of Kashmir. But on his visit to the region this week, Secretary of State Colin Powell should try to coax India into making some form of reciprocal gesture to Pakistan, perhaps by pulling back some of its forces on the border. General Musharraf's speech was the second critical turnabout for Pakistan since Sept. 11. The first came when, under American pressure, Pakistan ended its support of the Taliban in Afghanistan. Repudiating the Taliban and Osama bin Laden was widely supported throughout Pakistan. Ending support for Muslim guerrillas in the disputed Indian state of Kashmir may not be so popular. General Musharraf made a powerful case for it, saying that ending support for groups attacking civilians in India offered the best path toward changing Indian policy on Kashmir.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Secretary of State Colin Powell, on his visit to India and Pakistan, should try to coax India into making some reciprocal gesture for Gen Pervez Musharraf's new crackdown on violent Islamic groups in Pakistan; says Musharraf has done more to crush these militant groups than many experts thought possible, and India owes Pakistan positive response; says if Pakistan truly ends its overt support for armed insurgency in Kashmir, it will be up to India to begin engaging in serious discussions about that state's political future

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    After the lies about his academic and athletic past came to light, George O'Leary immediately resigned as head football coach at the University of Notre Dame, because, in his words, ''the integrity and credibility of Notre Dame i...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: After the lies about his academic and athletic past came to light, George O'Leary immediately resigned as head football coach at the University of Notre Dame, because, in his words, ''the integrity and credibility of Notre Dame is impeccable'' (front page, Dec. 15). After the lies of Joseph J. Ellis were uncovered -- lies he routinely told his students regarding his political and military experience during the 1960's, not to mention his own athletic past -- this eminent historian did not resign from Mount Holyoke College. BURKE GRIGGS Boston, Dec. 15, 2001 The writer is an assistant professor of history at Boston College.

docs.snippet: Foreign Minister Soledad Alvear said the ambassadors to Cuba and Switzerland had been summoned home for consultations about left-wing guerrillas who escaped from a Santiago prison in 1996 and later surfaced in those countries. Switzerland acknowle...
docs.lead_paragraph: Foreign Minister Soledad Alvear said the ambassadors to Cuba and Switzerland had been summoned home for consultations about left-wing guerrillas who escaped from a Santiago prison in 1996 and later surfaced in those countries. Switzerland acknowledges granting asylum to one of the guerrillas but Fidel Castro has denied offering refuge to any of the escapees and his government has criticized Chile's insistence on pressing for more information about the matter. Larry Rohter (NYT)
docs.abstract: Chilean Foreign Min Soledad Alvear recalls ambassadors to Cuba and Switzerland for consultations about left-wing guerillas who escaped from Santiago prison in 1996 and later surfaced in those countries (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Two Envoys Recalled

docs.snippet: To speak to many Kashmiris today is to be told of Mohandas K. Gandhi's visit here in 1947. As Hindus and Muslims slaughtered each other during the partition of the subcontinent into India and Pakistan, Kashmiris spared each other the same fate. Ga...
docs.lead_paragraph: To speak to many Kashmiris today is to be told of Mohandas K. Gandhi's visit here in 1947. As Hindus and Muslims slaughtered each other during the partition of the subcontinent into India and Pakistan, Kashmiris spared each other the same fate. Gandhi described the Kashmir valley as a ray of hope in the darkness. To speak to many Kashmiris today is also to be told of the unspeakable curse that has since fallen on them.
docs.abstract: Rival claims over Kashmir go to heart of identities of Pakistan, which controls about third of region, and India, which controls rest; Pakistan holds it was created to offer homeland to subcontinent's Muslims, including Kashmir's Muslim majority; India sees Muslim state as necessary to its mantle as secular, multiethnic democracy; accuses Pakistan of waging proxy war in Kashmir by arming and training militants; map; chronology of key points in Kashmir's history; photo (M)

headline.main: Struggle for Kashmir Is Fueled By Clashing National Narratives
